Title: A disappointing stroller from a great brand
Body: I am a BIG Baby Jogger stroller fan. I own 2 different models, and I use them constantly. They are sturdy, reliable, and the customer service from Baby Jogger cannot be beat. When it came time to try an ultra-compact stroller for an upcoming trip, I was absolutely sure that the City Tour 2 would be the right stroller for us.I was so disappointed to get the stroller and experience how wobbly it is. The front wheels clack loudly and shake with each roll, even on a totally smooth indoor surface. I checked the wheels several times to make sure it wasn't an issue with installation - it's just how they are made.Compared to other ultra-compact strollers we tried, the folding mechanism is also cumbersome and awkward. I also wish that it would fold in a way that didn't require the removal of the wheels to fit in an airplane's overhead bin.On the bright side, the seat seems very comfortable and sturdy. The brake is easy to use. The fabric seems sturdy. It's offered at a great price point, and the inclusion of a travel bag is a great perk.Basically, this is an otherwise great stroller with an absolutely terrible set of wheels and a bad folding mechanism. Using this stroller on a busy travel day would drive me crazy. Definitely returning.

Title: Compact/lightweight travel stroller with flaws
Body: Pros: compact and lightweight (usually fits in overheard on airplane)Cons: not easy enough fold/unfold (sometimes requires two hands or using your foot to kick it out to pop into place), wheels are cheap and meant for very smooth surface only, uncomfortable for baby.1) It takes some getting used to to pop it open and close it up - Often a 2 handed operation. 2) One of the wheels rattles and the wheels aren't meant to be taken even on sidewalks, let alone brick or off road. Author: Dan
Title: So close to being great
Body: This stroller is so nearly perfect for travel. I used it on one short trip and it was awesome for manuevering one handed through the airport while I wheeled luggage in the other hand. My XL toddler fit well in the seat. The buckle was initially a hassle but I figured out a hack for just keeping the 2 side pieces permanently together so I wasn't trying to fit all 4 pieces together every time. The basket below is okay not amazing because it won't fit a full size backpack, but neither will any ultra compact travel stroller that I'm aware of. It folds down pretty compact and is relatively light and easy to carry, especially with the nice bag that's provided. The deal breaker for me was the fold. The buttons to activate the fold were so stiff I couldn't manage them one handed. And even with two hands I constantly struggled to get the folding mechanism to activate. I don't have weak hands but this thing really requires a lot of fumbling and that is just not okay when you are trying to get it folded quickly in a jet bridge or any other situation where you don't want to spend a full minute cursing quietly as strangers offer to help you while you're struggling. Perhaps this would have loosened up over time, but this stroller was meant to be a travel companion to make life easier, not our daily driver, so I didn't want to struggle with it every time we really needed it. Even all that said, I may have still sucked it up and kept it if I hadn't gotten a great deal on a Joolz Aer, which folds SO much easier and is comparable in all other aspects to this model.

Author: Kotaro Fujimaki
Title: A wheel broke after 5 moths of usage
Body: I believe many people write their reviews shortly after they receive their products. Here, I write a review after using Baby Jogger¬Æ City Tour‚Ñ¢ 2 Ultra-Compact Travel Stroller for 5 months. I should note that we used it almost everyday and not just for travel purposes, and we mostly kept the stroller on paved sidewalks.Overall, I am very disappointed by this stroller because of its apparent low durability. After 4 months of usage, the left wheel broke. The black metal piece that held the wheel apparently fell off and went missing. We bought a replacement wheel for $45. However, the same thing happened to the other side of the wheel a month later. I attached the photo of the wheel with the missing piece; the red dashed circle is where the metal piece was.Besides the fragility of its wheels, I really liked the maneuverability of this stroller and its light weight, which made it easy to carry my child in a busy city like Boston. Maybe it's good for occasional use, but if you're thinking of using it for everyday purposes, I will not recommend it.

Author: Michelle P.
Title: A Solid 4.5 Stars, Excellent Alternative to YoYo
Body: I have been using this stroller for 4 months, since my daughter was 4 months old. I wanted an alternative to the expensive YOYO2 that we could use for flying as well as our daily keep-in-the-car stroller for errands. It has met all my general expectations and it's half the price of the YOYO. Here are the pros and cons:Pros:Small. Fits in airline overhead bins at least on large planes. The photo shows it fitting in the few inches of space in the back of my 2014 Kia Sorento with the 3rd row seats up.Easy to fold up. I usually use 2 hands to complete the process but the first mechanism can be done one handed. Technically you could probably do it all one handed, but two helps.Easy to maneuver with one handFoot rest and reclineNice sun shade with mesh peekaboo windowMy 4.5 year old fits it in too in a pinchComes with carrying bag for travelCons:Unfolding is easy but not graceful. The thing kind of flies open and I've had pieces of it hit me on the shin multiple times.The straps/buckles are awkward as heck. I don't know what kind of sadist designed the buckles to come apart into 4 separate pieces, but I've had to puzzle them back together like the magic scarab beetle in Aladdin before I can buckle it up properly quite a few times. I'm planning to try some duct tape on the backside of the buckle pieces to see if that will hold them together better. This is a small annoyance but my biggest pet peeve about this stroller.The seat is easy to lower (recline) using one hand, but to lift it back up into a more upright position again takes two and a little fiddling. That mechanism is very basic.The seat itself is a very flat piece of material with nothing that contours to the baby in any way, so I always think my daughter looks a little lopsided in it. She seems happy enough in it though. Maybe less of an issue for older babies and toddlers who hold themselves up better.No cupholder or anything on the handle bar, but this is not a deal breaker for meSmall basket, but it's a compact stroller, what do you expect?This worked great for us in the airport and on several international flights. I can't guarantee it would fit in the overhead bin on a smaller plane, but on long hauls you are good to go! It's light, folds easy, and maneuvers really well for such a compact stroller. I'm glad I bought it and saved a bunch of money compared to the YOYO, but have to take off half a star or so for the annoying buckle situation.

Title: Overall great compact stroller.
Body: This is a great compact stroller that feels pretty sturdy and durable. I compared it against the mountain buggy nano, and cybex libelle. I also thought the fold wasn't as easy and quick as I thought it was going to be. I kind of had to force it closed each time. The fabric also seemed like it would be less dirt and stain resistant.As for the baby jogger it is compact enough to take on a plane, it folds super easily, and the fabric is easy to clean. My only complaints are that I wish the seat back was a little longer and went higher up to accommodate a growing toddler/child, it also would have been nice if it could stand on its own in the folded position, and I wish the carry bag was more fitted and hand backpack straps and a handle. The bag makes the stroller look much larger than it is.I hope someone finds this review helpful!

Author: Kira Jankowski
Title: The convenience of a (almost) full sized stroller, but so light and compact!
Body: We bought this stroller for upcoming trips in December and February, and were really concerned about getting a stroller that would be a breeze to fly with, but still look like a normal stroller and have all the amenities we are used to with our everyday stroller. I think we definitely found it with this stroller!Assembly was quick, out of the box it took about 5 minutes to unfold, clip in the wheels and lock them into place. We got the all black version of the stroller and it looks really sleek. It's super light and the added carrying bag will be really nice for when we are in airports and need to tuck the stroller away when boarding a flight, especially if we aren't able to store it in an overhead bin and will need to gate check it.As we haven't used it fully yet, some pros out of the box:- Really lightweight and the positioning of the handle bar is nice. I'm 5'3 and my husband is 6'2 and we both can comfortably push this and maneuver it.- It's also very narrow, which again will be convenient when traveling. With our other sturdier stroller, the back wheels stick out quite a bit and I'm always bumping the stroller into things when we go out to stores and such.- Love the fact that the seat can fully recline and the sun shade covers a decent amount. It's comparable to our Evenflo stroller for shade coverage. The adjustable foot rest is really nice and easy to use.- While I don't think it's foldable with one hand, it isn't hard to break down the stroller and fold it up.- Included carrying case is nice for keeping it stored and clean. Also has a strap for easy carrying on the case.- It folds down so small and compact! Our other stroller we need to put a seat down in our GMC Acadia to fit it in the trunk (which is so small) and really inconvenient for our older kids that sit in the back. This folds down so compact it fits in our very limited space in the trunk area.- It looks like a normal stroller. Some of the other compact strollers that we looked into are so weird looking when fully unfolded. I like that it just looks like your standard stroller.- It's very sturdy feeling for a compact stroller. It's a good middle ground between a higher quality umbrella stroller and an everyday/bulkier stroller.Some cons:- The underneath basket is pretty small. I think we'd be able to comfortably put a spare blanket or two under there, and maybe a few stray items. It definitely is not large enough for a full diaper bag, but that's not a deal breaker for us.- The chest clip/5 point harness is a little cumbersome to use. It breaks apart into separate pieces, and can be a little tricky to line up just right to clip. If your kid is struggling or wiggly, it can be a little difficult to get all the pieces together. I wish you could lock the top straps into place instead of just sliding them into the clips- It is a little tricky to unfold. We had looked at this stroller in the store prior to buying online, and the sales lady said you can just flip the stroller really hard and it'll open and lock into place. I don't think this is the case at all. There's a clip on the side you need to release to unfold it completely, and even then sometimes the folding points don't lock together when opening it up on the first time. I think it would be super difficult to open this one handed or if you were holding a baby. It takes me two hands. But once you know what you are doing it's not hard to open.- It's a little difficult to carry if you aren't using the carrying bag. If you are just folding it back up and throwing it in your trunk it's fine, but if you need to carry it around I'd definitely make sure you have the carrying case along.- The wheels are pretty small. If you aren't using it for indoors (malls/shopping/etc) or on pavement I think it would be pretty hard to maneuver. Especially on grass, gravel, or uneven terrain.
Styles: Style: City Tour 2 Stroller | Color: Pitch Black

Author: GA Reviewer
Title: Folds up flat and square- very compact shape. Smooth rolling. Terrible strap snaps.
Body: We used to own a baby jogger style Stroller as a go to stroller- a big 3 wheel vehicle that took up my whole SUV trunk and a big part of a pickup bed and now with this stroller I‚Äôm literally in shock about how SMALL this folds up. It‚Äôs about the size of a really big diaper bag. I have a trunk back! I can finally put groceries in there- so exciting.I‚Äôve owned probably about 5 strollers by now a few kids in and I will say this is also SUPER easy to open and close, get in and out of trunk, etc. Some of my other strollers were HEAVY and were honestly too hard to maneuver postpartum (c section healing). This is LIGHT compared to most others. It‚Äôs heavier than a standard fabric and frame umbrella stroller but way lighter than any jogger or double stroller I‚Äôve had. Which is amazing considering there‚Äôs multiple positions for the kid and a small storage fabric tray under. I actually find it easier to open and close than a cheap standard umbrella stroller. This would be a great vacation/ airport stroller.It comes with a travel bag which although useful for travel, I don‚Äôt bother with it on a day to day basis. I usually just want to open and close fast in and out of trunk.It rolls very smooth and maneuvers great. Night and day easier over a bulky jogger or double strollers that I was using a lot.There‚Äôs no cup holders or any pockets or anything useful on the handle AND there‚Äôs a warning about not hanging things from it. I assume this is because if the stuff you are putting in it is too heavy you could tip it over (it‚Äôs pretty lightweight). I will honestly probably put a few accessories on it though- as a cup holder and phone holder would have been useful when I go for walks w/ baby- but I don‚Äôt think I could hang Shopping bags from it like my intense heavy double stroller.The seat folds all the way down flat so baby can lap flat (nice). I had trouble figuring how to get it back up To sitting again on my own and left the kid laying down because I couldn‚Äôt figure it out when in use- but my husband seemed to figure it out with no issues.The straps are a total pain. I own a million strollers and about 7 car seats and high chairs, etc- so I‚Äôm used to these different straps from different brands- but these are just plain annoying. There are two top pieces that need to slide into middle pieces and then those go into a middle. Excerpt those top shoulder straps are super hard to slide into the side ones- and when getting multiple kids out of a car in a parking lot I‚Äôve literally just only strapped in his sides around the waist because I don‚Äôt have the time to curse and fumble and mess with these shoulder straps. If they slid in smoother it would be fine- but it‚Äôs TIGHT and hard to line up because everything is black. I could see struggling with this part if I had my fake nails on. This would be a hard strap for my mother too w/ arthritis issues.I even used this seat at beach and walked baby around then dragged this through the sand under a tent and baby napped on the beach for an hour laying down on this like a nap cot.Overall I‚Äôd recommend it.

Author: Outdoor Enthusiast | Geek | Photographer
Title: Good stroller, but suffers same issue as other side-by-side double strollers
Body: A couple of my friends own double strollers. Two have side-by-side ones, and one has a front-and-back. Each have their Pros and Cons, and how does this Baby Jogger fare?PROS- Fairly lightweight- Comparable pricing- Comfortable seats- Fits through most doors- Folds easily and uses less space than two, separate strollers- Takes up VERY little space- Cargo space available- Smooth tires (initially)- Sun shade for both children are generously sized and come down quite a bit- Near-flat recline for napping (they work independently from the other)- Three-point safety harnesses- Leg support with adjustable angles- Rated for children up to 2 years/33 lbs each- Compatible with optional carry cotsCONS- One of the front tires became difficult to turn after having taken the stroller through some graveled terrain. All 4 wheels used to turn smoothly on concrete, but not any more- Suffers from the same issue as other side-by-side strollers when occupied by two children of vastly different weights (see NOTES below)- Can be considered pricey for some, but the ability to only push one instead of two strollers is well worth the convenience- Does not come with cup holders for neither the parent nor the toddlers, though you can buy third party accessories for the parent side- No cart seat attachment, though car seat stroller straps work- Cargo space is a bit on the small sideNOTES- If the stroller is used only for smooth, concrete terrain, the wheels should last for a long time and provide for a smooth ride. Do not use them over rough terrain, such as gravel as I did, or you could potentially damage one or more wheels- Four-wheeled design makes it harder to jog with, but much more stable for strolling around the city. For jogging, get the three-wheeled designs for easier, one-handed maneuverability- Like many side-by-side strollers, if both children are vastly different in weight, the heavier toddler will skew the stroller to turn more towards that side. You can easily compensate for that, however. Front-to-back strollers do not have that problem, but they suffer from the child sitting at the back from not being able to see what is going on up frontAll in all, this double stroller works well, but the reliability and hardiness of the wheels are questionable in the long-run, particularly for rough terrain.
Styles: Style: City Tour 2 Double Stroller | Color: Pitch Black

Author: La Vida Loca YT Keeping Up With The Reviews
Title: 0-24 months old - narrow and great for small sidewalks and entryways
Body: Each seat supports child from 0-24 months old. That being said if there is a big difference between the kids in weight you will feel it when taking turns. My kids are about 8lbs apart and I FEEL it. It‚Äôs much easier taking turns if kids are close in weight. Seats can individually recline nearly flat and calf support can be adjusted to flat position so the kids can actually get a good sleep in this stroller. Canopy is generously sized but I don‚Äôt like the peakaboo window because it makes noise when opening. I woke my baby up twice. I just try not to completely close it to avoid the velcro making noise. Ride is smooth and the stroller turns easily. It‚Äôs narrow enough for our narrow sidewalks and I have no issues with the clearance like I do with the full size double stroller. Folding and unfolding is easy but it‚Äôs not exactly one hand operation, at least not for me and not yet. All things considered, functionality and ease of use I consider this to be a very good and fairly lightweight stroller. This will not last for kids pass 2yr old as the seats will get narrow. Author: Adam Shields
Title: Very light for a double stroller, narrow so easy to maneuver, but the storage is too small
Body: I have had a lot of strollers over the years as a nanny and then my own kids. This is a very light, easy to fold double stroller. It folds pretty flat so that you can put it in a trunk without it taking up too much space. It is good for use on a bus or public transportation where you need to squeeze in beside it.There are two negatives to it. One, when putting it up, there are two different points that have to be clicked in and both need to be manually put into place. Some strollers just unfold and automatically click into place. This one needs you to move it into place. Which if you have a second adult with you, is not a big deal. If you don't that takes some effort if you are putting it up while managing two little kids.Second problem is that the under stroller storages is very small. I tend to bring a backpack as a diaper bag or carrying whatever I need. Because of how narrow the opening is, I needed to use a smaller backpack and it takes more effort to get it into the storage area. I used another similar style stroller a few weeks ago and it had a significantly larger strorage area and I missed that.This does not come with a cup holder, but there is a space to hang one. That being said, these type of cup holders tend to fall off and get lost fairly easily so I am not surprised that one did not come with it.Now the positives. It is small, narrow and easy to get through doors. It is as light as any double stroller that I have used. But that lightness and narrowness is in part because it is designed for kids up to 33 each. Larger kids both will be uncomfortable because the seats are too narrow and because the stroller will likely crack a wheel or stop turning correctly if it is regularly used with too much weight.The sunshades come way down and the seats lay nearly flat. That along with the feet area locking into a flat position makes this a great stroller for kids to nap in.There is not a cup holder or pocket for kids. The kids that are using this probably are too small to use those on their own anyway, but I know for my 4 year old (he is about 40lbs) he wants a pocket or something to put his stuff.There is a good lock on the wheels and the turning works well as long as it is not overloaded.

Title: Recommend for twins or kids close in age! (Max Limit: 33lbs/side)
Body: Love how slim the stroller is and it looks quite nice too with the canopy - fits through doorways fine, fairly easy to maneuver for a double stroller. The product description says for 0-24 months and the max limit per side is 33 pounds (for reference that's about how much my 2.5 year old weighs), so works best if your kids are close in age or twins. The weight limit is quite low, so unless your kid is smaller, this wouldn't be recommended for anyone 3 years and up. It's also quite narrow, so they wouldn't fit comfortably. The reclining is pretty good, reclines a decent amount so baby's can nap. It's a little difficult to open and close (only because it is larger than a single stroller) but considering the size, still quite easy to do. Simply press the top handlebar and move another button left while adjusting the stroller - and it becomes quite compact in seconds! Fits well in the trunk - folds down even smaller than my uppababy cruz (single stroller)!

Author: Angie
Title: Folds up Unbelievably small!
Body: The first thing you notice is just how small this full size stroller folds up to. It arrived in a box that was so small I thought I might need to do a lot of assembling, but nope. All I had to do was attach the wheels. both sets clicked into place so easily it took less than thirty seconds and required no tools. The unique folding mechanism means the stroller folds into thirds and is about the size of a large tote bag when it is finished. It is perfect for traveling (I would think it would fit in an overhead locker on a plane) and for maximizing the space in your boot. Unfolding is simple but takes a little practice simply because it folds differently to other strollers I have owned so you have to have a couple of practices to get the 'knack'.The buggy will accommodate your child from birth through to 4/5 years old. The back of the chair lies almost flat and the from raises to provide a secure 'bed' but you can also buy extra attachments (the Graco one was just under $20) so you can click in your car seat.The wheels are solid, so no tires to pump and the center of gravity is further forward than most strollers so no tipping!. The stroller is light and maneuverable, easy to control and steer with one hand. There is a small amount of storage - not very much- this is probably the sacrifice you have to make for it folding up so neatly.

Author: Ricardo & Krystal Torres
Title: Baby Jogger City Tour 2 Seacrest
Body: I recieved the stroller today. I haven't taken out for a stroll yet. The stroller is lightweight. I'm going from using a Chicco Bravo stroller to the city tour. It definitely is something to get use to since the chicco is much more spacious. The latch used to lock the stroller only locks the bottom part of the stroller not the handle, so if I pick up the stroller from the handle instead of the strap it'll open up the stroller. The canopy is a little awkward, when I open it all the way and the seat is up all tr he way the canopy is really close to the child's face. The brakes are good. The push handle is comfortable. When I opened the back part of the stroller to readjust the straps you can see the back panel it's made of a plastic board as I'm sure a lot of stroller are. The storage basket is a joke. I have a skip hop diaper bag that I usually hang on the push handle but the city tour has a warning sign on the canopy to not hang bags from the handle. Plus this stroller doesn't come with a belly bar I had to purchase separate which is ridiculous considering the price.For the price of the stroller I expected a little more. I feel like I paid for the brand name more than the actual stroller.For an everyday stroller this is ok I wouldn't use it to travel. Author: D. Sweet
Title: Compact/Travel Stroller - Not an Everyday Stroller, a few pointers!
Body: From a Baby Jogger fan, this is a great travel stroller, but not a good everyday stroller in my opinion. I'm not a fan of the two-way break apart buckle for each side, that's just an extra hassle and I've considered super gluing the top piece into the second side piece. The seat back is almost too short for my 18 month old to rest his head on while riding, as you recline the seat the back pocket will sort of cradle their heads somewhat, but I can't imagine that being particularly comfortable. This being said, I didn't purchase this for my everyday stroller, but for a lightweight travel/shopping stroller alternative vs my older City Elite model (Summit sized version). I also have a the Double GT.If I were a new parent, searching for a stroller I would say this - I love my Elite, but it is big and heavy and I don't always need/want to carry the bulk, but when I want the features, it sure is nice! The City Mini GT wasn't out when I purchased the Elite, or I would have gotten that one for sure! The GT Double, is amazing, but also heavy. The functionality on both my Elite and GT Double is excellent and I love in every way. I have a smaller 7.5 year old that can still fit comfortably in either the Elite or the GT Double, and our 4.5 year old still fits just fine as well. The canopies are huge, and a really appreciated feature that is always needed to shade our kiddos!Overall the Tour 2 is obviously a small stroller, but if you are wanting a stroller to last throughout toddler-hood (and beyond when needed) - I would not recommend this one, but would advise to choose between the GT2 or the City Mini 2 which would last much longer, and provide a much more comfortable ride for your kiddos. The Tour 2 is all about convenience but doesn't offer the complete package of functionality, comfort, or the big canopy to shade my little one. The City Mini is just over 4 lbs heaver at 18.8 lbs, and is well worth the upgrade and the price tag (as is the GT, at 21.4 lbs). For the Tour 2, the ability to hold a car seat for travel would be a huge plus if we were in that stage still I must say, the fold is fantastic, maneuverability is wonderful, fabric should hold up and clean well, however, I do think the basket/material could feel a little more durable given these often get heavy use.If this is your travel/airport/shopping stroller, I'd look around for one that might accommodate a taller toddler for the head rest issue I see with this one - otherwise this is a great small stroller that boasts the ability to fit carry on requirements when traveling.Pictured, average size 18 month old, and 4.5 year old. And folded in my Honda Odyssey.

Author: Joanna P
Title: Lightweight, good quality, nice features
Body: New baby update: I‚Äôve been using this as an infant car seat stroller for my Chicco Key Fit with the belly bar and a nylon strap secured through the seat belt path. With the strap it is similar to other travel strollers with universal infant seat holders. I‚Äôve been using a jogging stroller as my main stroller since quarantine started and this feels flimsy in comparison but I‚Äôm guessing similar to other snap and go frames. My 2.5 year old can still fit the seat and a small potty seat fits in the under basket.Update: after nearly a year of use, this stroller still performs great. The wheels squeak a bit and I have to pop the front wheels over uneven spots on the sidewalk, but I love how the stroller is sturdy but lightweight. I got the belly bar to attach a clip-on snack cup and to have a handle for carrying. My tall 19 month old fits but will probably exceed the height before the 44 lb weight limit.Original review: I bought this stroller to replace a City Mini GT with my 11 month old. We live in an old building with stairs to the sidewalk, and I could not manage a heavy stroller and baby on my own anymore. I went to a big box store and tried out other options (including the $400+ ones and the sub-$200 ones). The expensive ones are nicer but too expensive, and the cheaper ones feel low quality and uncomfortable for baby. I bought an Ergobaby Metro and the City Tour 2 to try at home and kept this one. This is a great middle-level travel stroller. This stroller pushes ok on uneven concrete and fair on dirt and low grass. On sidewalks and smoother surfaces, you can push one-handed. The folding mechanism isn‚Äôt as smooth as Ergobaby Metro or Uppababy Minu, but I can do it one handed now after using it a few weeks. Opening is also awkward but manageable holding my baby on my hip. The underseat storage will hold a medium-sized purse or small diaper bag. My backpack diaper bag would not fit. The canopy covers to about mid-torso (compared to ankle-level in the GT), so a raincover is a must. My son has sat in this stroller for errands and neighborhood strolls without complaint. The seat length is comparable to the Mountain Buggy Nano and it does dip a little to keep him from sliding out. I put up the leg rest for now since he is too short to overhang. I like that the seat back can go very upright, he likes looking around, but he can also grab the frame and pull himself almost out of the stroller so I keep the harness tight. The harness clips are annoying but seem secure. One nice feature is that once folded, if you tilt the front wheels sideways, this balances upright enough to lean on a wall (compared to the GT which was very prone to tipping when folded). The carry bag has a shoulder strap but no backpack straps, and they got rid of the zipper pouch in the storage basket and pocket behind the seat. I wish there was a built-in strap for carrying since the handle you pull to fold is a skinny and chafing piece of nylon. I‚Äôm giving this 5 stars because this is an amazing value for a travel stroller that looks and handles more like a full-sized stroller. For new parents, this can replace a caddy stroller and umbrella stroller (and maybe a full-sized stroller). I‚Äôll update if needed after traveling with it this summer.

Author: GMT23
Title: BEST TRAVEL STROLLER ON THE MARKET
Body: I didn't buy this stroller on amazon but felt I needed to write a review due to the lack of reviews for this stroller out there. This is a relatively new stroller (came out in February). While I never used the original city tour, this review is solely for the new version (the tour 2). I live on the other side of the country with my family all back east and have traveled already 4x with my 6 month old. I am so relieved to have found a stroller that is a combination of all the travel strollers out there. I was pretty much buying a stroller than returning it after using it for one trip because the others are so impractical. I started with the Baby zen yoyo (i hated how you needed two hands to fold, the price and lack of storage). Then I tried the Uppababy minu (I use the Uppababy Vista as my primary full size stroller). I was really hoping to like it but it fell short since it was heavy and couldn't elevate legs so baby can nap. Then I tried the gbpockit plus. The only thing i liked about this stroller was the price, other than that its total garbage and very flimsy. I only used it for 1 round trip at airport because I was certain it would break since its so cheaply made. Then finally, i discovered the baby jogger city tour 2!It was honestly a relief and words don't describe how happy I am to have finally found one thats both functional and doesn't look strange. I love that it has a one hand fold (i can open and close it all while holding my baby). It has decent storage space, comes to a close full recline for naps, foot rest also comes up, and it doesn't feel like my son will tip over in it. My son seemed comfortable and didn't get fussy in the stroller. It has a nice stride and easy to maneuver. It also comes with a nice bag to store it in. Fantastic stroller and highly highly recommend if you are a frequent traveler looking for a nice carry on stroller (it fit in overhead for american airlines, jet blue and delta). Extra plus, it comes at fraction of the cost of the other more popular options.*I didn't try the mountain buggy because it felt cheap and reminded me too much of the GBpockit plus.

However as this was one of the things addressed with the city tour 2, I went for it. After a 12 hour day at Disney, this thing delivers. Super light, narrow, easy to maneuver, quick to fold, decent basket for a stroller this compact, the full recline and popped foot rest were great for on the go naps, the seat depth was good for both my giant kid and my 4 year old niece. Sun shade is a bit small especially if the seat is as far forward/straight as it will go but it‚Äôs still decent. Very happy with our purchase!UPDATE: 6 months later still loving our city tour! The one bummer to note is we are frequent Alaska Airlines travelers and based on their newer carry on policy re: dimensions, this is a tad too big to pass and did in fact fail when I was asked out put it in the carry-on sizer, even with wheels removed.
